issues.title: On other routing metrics
issues.author: giralt
issues.body: Explain if other "routing metrics" mentioned in IDR docs are relevant or if they can be referenced. (This was asked by Ketan during IETF 121.)

comments.author: muzixing
comments.body: We have a draft in IDR https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ll-idr-cats-bgp-extension-00, which defines the solution of using BGP for cats. In the basic mode, it uses the extensions in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-idr-5g-edge-service-metadata-24.  5G-edge draft defines a general mechanism with several TLVs. CATS may use some of them but not all.

comments.author: bpatient78
comments.body:
Hi, all, I've reviewed two drafts mentioned from Ketan, https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-idr-bgp-generic-metric/ and https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-lsr-flex-algo-bw-con-15.html#section-2 

The first draft is an extension of RFC 7311 AIGP which is a set of accumulated cost metrics used in IGP domain, to inter domain usage by leverging BGP extensions for generic metrics defined in the second draft. It names the new mechanism AMetric. 
Some should be noted that:

- these generic metrics typically refer to network metrics as described in Section 2 of draft-ietf-lsr-flex-algo-bw-con-15:
"The Traffic Engineering Default Metric is defined in [RFC5305] and [RFC3630] and the Min Unidirectional delay metric is defined in [RFC8570] and [RFC7471]. Other metrics, such as jitter, reliability, and fiscal cost may be helpful, depending on the traffic class."

- These two drafts are more on metric exposure and metric distribution rather than the definition of new metrics.
- As mentioned in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-idr-bgp-generic-metric/ , it keeps emphasizing accumulation which should be compared with aggregation that mentioned in our drafts. 
- Similarly, it has a definition on normalized bit(Section 5) and which component does normalization(Section 8), and the way to use this normalized value(Section 8 and 9). I think we should refer to this part when we consider to define our normalized CATS metrics.
- As Cheng mentioned above and also Lindar mentioned in the list, there are some other documents describing CATS related metrics and ways to exposure. We should also look into these docs and put them into the same discussion thread.

issues.title: On the normalization of L2 metrics
issues.author: giralt
issues.body:
Joel wrote on the mailing list:

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cats/_AR5_zq4eWs0a8sNfa7d4nvNRkg/

> I have  a question regarding section 3.3 of this draft.  That section 
> defines the L2 metrics, which I hope are the ones we will actually 
> communicate from servers to ingress edge devices.  The text says that 
> each service may have their own normalization method.  That makes 
> sense.  There was a question raised during the meeting that is separate 
> from that text, but related to it.  How do we envision independent 
> implementors of a given service will know how to normalize their metrics 
> such that the ingress edge device can compare the normalized metrics.  
> (I think it is achievable, I am just missing how we will do so.)

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: The service influences the traffic steering decisions of the network through the normalized metric. It does not matter how the service calculate the metric, as long as the metric is comparable.

comments.author: bpatient78
comments.body: Should we add a subsection for recommending a way for normalization? I think in CATS it is more important and more complex, since different components can do normalization. (BGP speaker, sevice contact instance, or edge cloud management system, at compute domain and network controller at network domain) They  may use different methods for normalization depending on what metrics they use.

issues.title: No service metrics defined yet
issues.author: luismcontreras
issues.body:
By now we are covering resource-related metrics (CPU, storage, etc).

I wonder if service-related metrics can be also part of the picture. For instance number of sessions, etc.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: This is a good suggestion. Number of sessions can help determine the load of a service instance.

comments.author: muzixing
comments.body: Will number of sessions impact the resource in the end? should we describe the final status of resources or a transit state of resource? I will like to avoid to use number of sessions. Because we can not tell how much resource is occupied by a session. Even they are not equal for each session.

comments.author: bpatient78
comments.body: Sometimes number of sessions is important, when it does not have a linear relationship with CPU resource occupation. Since handling different service sessions may take up different compute resources. In such case, maybe we should consider them, but it is very hard to give it cost when doing normalization.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: Discussion 11.20: sessions are inaccurate to measure the utilization.

issues.title: L2 metric: just one aggregated metric or one for compute and one for network?
issues.author: luismcontreras
issues.body: With the current definition of L2 metric, the generation of such L2 metric can only be performed on an element consolidating both network and compute metrics. That is, the C-PS (or the Ingress C-Forwader), according to the current framework definition. It could be maybe more practical if we can consider L2 metrics per domain so that both C-SMA and C-NMA can generate L2 metrics per domain that later on can be consolidated in C-PS (or the Ingress C-Forwader), but avoiding the burden of transmitting all the L1 metrics up to C-PS (or the Ingress C-Forwader).

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: My understanding of metric in this document is all about compute domain metric, not network domain metric.

comments.author: bpatient78
comments.body:
I think Luis's comment makes sense, we should consider separately when generating the L2 metrics. But will it be a L3 metric if these L2 metrics generated from different agents and domain. L2 from C-NMA is for path selection considering network domain metrics only. L2 from C-SMA is for instance selection considering compute domain metrics only. So can they be simply summed up at the Ingress(C-PS)? If not, will there be a simple derivation and generation of another value(L3 metric)?. I'm not recommending we should have a L3 abstraction, but try to understand such case. Welcome for discussion.:) 

> My understanding of metric in this document is all about compute domain metric, not network domain metric.

to Vincent, this document is about CATS metrics, so it will cover both network and compute domain, even if we may not define new network metrics, considering large amout of work in network metrics definition. Metrics in network domain is for the derivation of CATS metrics.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: By domain I mean the source of the metric. That is to say, the metric defined in this document comes from computing side, not network side. Is that correct?

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: Discussion @11.20: Do we need to separate the network domain metric and computing domain metric? They should follow the same absctration principle.
